Nullpointers

All pointervariables have a special value “nullptr” meaning that this pointer is not pointing att anything. This is to make it possible to check if a pointer is pointing at something or at nothing. But if a pointer variable is not initiated it will have an undefined value and if used the program will normally crash. If you try to dereference a nullptr the program will also crash but the difference is that it is possible to check if the pointer has a nullptr value or not.

Note: You should use “nullptr” to test if a pointer has a “nullptr” value but from historical reasons it is common to see “NULL”, “null” or “0” used instead.

One programmingstyle is to allways set a pointer to nullptr in the declaration.

Kodexempel A

Övningsuppgift 1

Vad skrivs ut till konsolfönstret av följande kod?

Svar:

Probably the result was something like “0x000000” since nullptr normally has value 0

Övningsuppgift 2

Vad skrivs ut till konsolfönstret av följande kod?

####Svar: Probably the program crashed since the pointer was not initiated!

Kommentar

a pointer value can be treated as a boolean, it will then evaluate to false if it is the null pointer and true otherwise.
